summary: The Time Traveller presents his theory of the fourth dimension, Time, to his dinner guests, challenging conventional ideas about geometry and existence. He explains that just as the three spatial dimensions are essential for the existence of objects, so is duration or time. The guests are skeptical but intrigued, with some attempting to grasp the concept and others dismissing it as implausible. Despite their doubts, the Time Traveller claims to have experimental evidence and hints at having built a machine capable of time travel, before leaving the room. His departure piques the curiosity of the guests, leading to speculation about his experiment's nature.

nodes.label: The Time Traveller
nodes.title: The main character who is discussing complex ideas about space and time with his guests

nodes.label: Filby
nodes.title:
An argumentative person with red hair, part of the Time Traveller's audience and a skeptic of his
theories

nodes.label: Psychologist
nodes.title: A character who engages in the discussion about the Time Traveller's theories

nodes.label: The Medical Man
nodes.title:
Another guest who participates in the conversation, particularly in relation to the movement in
space and time

nodes.label: The Very Young Man
nodes.title: A character who attempts to relight his cigar and participates in the discussion with simpler input

nodes.label: The Provincial Mayor
nodes.title: A character who is trying to understand the Time Traveller's theories

edges.label: explained and countered
edges.title:
"Can a cube that does not last for any time at all, have a real existence?" Filby became pensive.
"Why not?" said the Time Traveller.

edges.label: questioned and was unconvinced by
edges.title:
"Is not that rather a large thing to expect us to begin upon?" said Filby. "You can show black is
white by argument," said Filby, "but you will never convince me.”

edges.label: not informed and contemplated
edges.title: “I have not,” said the Provincial Mayor. “Yes, I think I see it now,” he said.

edges.label: inquired and warned
edges.title:
“But,” said the Medical Man, "why cannot we move in Time as we move about in the other dimensions of
Space?” “Don’t you think you would attract attention?” said the Medical Man.

edges.label: differentiated and was skeptical about
edges.title:
"You can move about in all directions of Space, but you cannot move about in Time.” “Of all the wild
extravagant theories!” began the Psychologist.

summary: The Time Traveller presented a small, intricate machine to his guests, claiming it could travel through time. He demonstrated it to a skeptical group, made up of the Psychologist, the Medical Man, the Provincial Mayor, and others, who closely observed the machine and its operation without noticing any trickery. The machine then vanished from sight after the Psychologist was invited to activate it. The Time Traveller asserted the disappearance was genuine, explained the concept using psychology, and offered to show the larger, nearly completed version of the machine in his laboratory. Despite the demonstration and explanation, the guests seemed incredulous but curious.

nodes.label: The Time Traveller
nodes.title: The inventor of the time machine and central character presenting his invention

nodes.label: The Psychologist
nodes.title: A skeptical character engaging with the Time Traveller about his invention

nodes.label: The Medical Man
nodes.title: A character who examines the time machine and interacts with the Time Traveller

nodes.label: The Provincial Mayor
nodes.title: A character who participates in the discussion and offers objections about the time travel theory

nodes.label: Filby
nodes.title: A character present in the room who reacts to the Time Traveller's claims and is skeptical

nodes.label: The Very Young Man
nodes.title: A minor character present during the Time Traveller's demonstration

edges.label: be behind
edges.title: Filby sat behind The Time Traveller.

edges.label: ask
edges.title:
The Medical Man asked The Time Traveller if he seriously believes that The Machine has travelled
into time.

edges.label: indicate
edges.title: The Time Traveller directed The Psychologist to use the lever.

summary: The narrator recounts skepticism around the Time Traveller's claims about time travel, suspecting his ingenuity rather than taking him seriously. At a gathering, the Time Traveller arrives disheveled and disturbed but withholds his story until he has eaten. Addressing the group's doubts and questions, he agrees to recount his remarkable experiences without interruption, though his tale sounds unbelievable. He claims to have lived eight extraordinary days since 4 pm that day.

nodes.label: Time Traveller
nodes.title: The main character who is capable of time travel and whose story is central to the narrative

nodes.label: Filby
nodes.title:
A character who is mentioned as an example to illustrate the skepticism of others toward the Time
Traveller

nodes.label: Medical Man
nodes.title: A character who discusses the Time Traveller's experiments and is present at the dinner

nodes.label: Editor
nodes.title: A character who attends the dinner and is skeptical of the Time Traveller’s claims

nodes.label: Psychologist
nodes.title: A character present at both dinners and offers explanations about the Time Traveller’s experiments

nodes.label: Blank
nodes.title: A character only mentioned in passing and present at the dinner

nodes.label: Journalist
nodes.title: A character present at the dinner who is skeptical and makes light of the time travel idea

nodes.label: Silent Man
nodes.title: A character present at the dinner who is quiet and does not offer much to the conversation

nodes.label: Hettie Potter
nodes.title: A character only mentioned in anecdotes by the Journalist, indirect relation to the main narrative

edges.label: discussion
edges.title:
The Medical Man had discussed the trick of the model with the Time Traveller and expressed concern
upon seeing him disheveled.

edges.label: expectation
edges.title:
The Editor expected an explanation about Time Traveller's absence and assisted by suggesting ringing
the bell for dinner.

edges.label: event narration
edges.title:
The Psychologist volunteered a wooden account of the “ingenious paradox and trick” the Time
Traveller had shown.

edges.label: non-communication
edges.title: The Silent Man was silent during the evening but poured wine for the Time Traveller.

edges.label: skepticism
edges.title: The Journalist was skeptical about the Time Traveller's time travelling claim.

edges.label: disbelief
edges.title: The fact is, the Time Traveller was one of those men who are too clever to be believed.

edges.label: explanation provision
edges.title: The Psychologist provided an explanation of the Time Traveller's demonstration to the Editor.

summary: Summary: The narrator describes testing his Time Machine, experiencing a harrowing and disorienting journey through time, witnessing the rapid alternation of days and nights, and the changing landscape. Upon stopping the machine, he finds himself in a future garden with unfamiliar architecture and encounters a group of small, delicate human-like beings after a moment of panic and struggle with his machine.

nodes.label: Time Traveller
nodes.title: The primary character who invents the Time Machine and experiences the sensations of time travel

nodes.label: Mrs. Watchett
nodes.title: The housekeeper of the Time Traveller, appearing briefly as she moves across the laboratory

nodes.label: White Sphinx
nodes.title:
A large sculpted figure seen by the Time Traveller in the future, representing mystery and possibly
the future civilization

nodes.label: Men running by the White Sphinx
nodes.title: Individuals in the distant future observed by the Time Traveller as he stops the machine

nodes.label: Creature in purple tunic
nodes.title: A frail-looking inhabitant of the future that approaches the Time Traveller on the little lawn

edges.label: enter
edges.title: "Mrs. Watchett came in and walked, apparently without seeing me, towards the garden door."

edges.label: approach
edges.title:
"Then I heard voices approaching me. Coming through the bushes by the White Sphinx were the heads
and shoulders of men running."

edges.label: spot
edges.title:
"One of these emerged in a pathway leading straight to the little lawn upon which I stood with my
machine."

summary: The narrator meets a group of delicate, childlike creatures in the future who express curiosity but no fear. They communicate in a melodic language and are fascinated by the Time Machine. The narrator attempts to prevent them from tampering with the machine and explores methods of communication, finding their intelligence level much lower than expected. He is adorned with flowers as a sign of affection and led to a building where he observes the simple and vegetarian lifestyle of these future beings. He begins to learn their language, though they tire easily and lose interest in teaching him.

nodes.label: I
nodes.title: The protagonist and narrator of the story, recounting an experience with future beings

nodes.label: Fragile thing out of futurity
nodes.title: One of the future beings who first approached the protagonist

nodes.label: Exquisite creatures
nodes.title: The group of future beings encountered by the protagonist

nodes.label: Little people
nodes.title: The collective term used by the narrator for the future beings

nodes.label: Fair-haired little creature
nodes.title: A specific member of the future beings who attempted to understand the protagonist's gestures

edges.label: face to face
edges.title: In another moment we were standing face to face, I and this fragile thing out of futurity.

edges.label: addressed
edges.title: One of them addressed me.

edges.label: saw confidence in
edges.title:
･ Indeed, there was something in these pretty little people that inspired confidence.
･ I could fancy myself flinging the whole dozen of them about like ninepins.
･ But I made a sudden motion to warn them when I saw their little pink hands feeling at the Time
Machine.
･ I determined to make a resolute attempt to learn the speech of these new men of mine.

edges.label: followed gesture
edges.title:
･ At once a quaintly pretty little figure in chequered purple and white followed my gesture.
･ and then astonished me by imitating the sound of thunder.
･ Then one of them suddenly asked me a question that showed him to be on the intellectual level of one
of our five-year-old children.
･ Then came one laughing towards me, carrying a chain of beautiful flowers altogether new to me, and
put it about my neck.

edges.label: gave vivid rendering
edges.title:
I nodded, pointed to the sun, and gave them such a vivid rendering of a thunderclap as startled
them.

edges.label: dined with
edges.title:
There were, perhaps, a couple of hundred people dining in the hall, and most of them, seated as near
to me as they could come, were watching me with interest.

summary: The narrator observes a lack of interest from the future humans, comparing their fleeting attention to that of children. After leaving a building and satisfying hunger, the narrator resolves to explore and understand the changed world, noticing various ruins and lack of small houses, speculating about the societal structure. Observing a uniformity in the future humans' appearance and clothing, the narrator theorizes about the absence of traditional gender roles and family structures, attributing this to a world where physical strength is no longer necessary. The world appears to be a perfectly maintained garden without signs of struggle or disease. This leads the narrator to contemplate the possibility of humanity's decline due to the lack of challenge and hardship, which once drove human development and adaptation. The narrator reflects on the triumphs over nature and ponders the consequences of such a utopia, where even the artistic spirit has nearly vanished, suggesting an ultimate contentment leading to stagnation. The narrator's initial interpretation sees the explanations as simple, yet realizes they may be incorrect or incomplete.

nodes.label: My little hosts
nodes.title:
The future inhabitants encountered by the traveler, with a described lack of sustained interest and
childlike behavior

nodes.label: I
nodes.title:
The narrator and time traveler who observes and speculates about the future world and its
inhabitants

nodes.label: Children
nodes.title:
The offspring of the future inhabitants observed by the narrator, showing precocious physical
development

nodes.label: Men of the future
nodes.title:
The adults of the future society who display uniformity in appearance and lack differentiation
between sexes

nodes.label: People of the future
nodes.title:
The general population of the future world encountered by the time traveler, living in security and
comfort without toil

edges.label: display astonishment
edges.title: They would come to me with eager cries of astonishment.

edges.label: meeting
edges.title: I was continually meeting more of these men of the future.

edges.label: follow and communicate
edges.title: Men of the future would follow me a little distance, chatter and laugh about me.

edges.label: appear similar
edges.title: And the children seemed to my eyes to be but the miniatures of their parents.

edges.label: lack differentiation
edges.title:
In costume, and in all the differences of texture and bearing that now mark off the sexes from each
other, these people of the future were alike.

summary: In the story, the protagonist is struck with fear and desperation when he realizes his Time Machine is missing. He frantically searches for it near the White Sphinx, where it was last seen, but to no avail. The Time Machine has vanished, and the protagonist is left to come to terms with his new reality in this strange world. He contemplates the idea that it has been hidden by some unknown power and grapples with the loss of his connection to his own time. Eventually, he resolves to stay calm and consider various plans, including building a new machine or finding the original one. His interactions with the little people are fraught with misunderstanding, and his actions driven by desperation lead to no success in recovering the Time Machine. He decides to adapt to his new surroundings, learn the language of the people there, and patiently wait for a solution to present itself, resigning himself to the irony of his situation.

nodes.label: Narrator
nodes.title: The person recounting the experience and the primary protagonist

nodes.label: White Sphinx
nodes.title:
A statue that the narrator sees which signifies mystery and has the Time Machine hidden within its
pedestal

nodes.label: Time Machine
nodes.title:
The invention created by the narrator enabling travel through time; central to the story, although
not a character itself

nodes.label: Little People
nodes.title:
Inhabitants of the world the narrator has travelled to; they interact with and react to the
narrator's actions

nodes.label: Owl
nodes.title: A creature the narrator mentions in passing to set the scene; its role is minor

nodes.label: Deer
nodes.title: Another creature the narrator mistakes in the dark; like the owl, its role is minor

nodes.label: Sparrows
nodes.title: Birds that are near the narrator when he wakes on the turf; they have a minor role

edges.label: Time Machine
edges.title: Little People, Owl, Deer, Sparrows'

edges.label: flitted by
edges.title: "a noiseless owl flitted by, and I shivered with the chill of the night."

edges.label: face towards
edges.title: "For the white leprous face of the sphinx was towards it."

edges.label: realize missing
edges.title: "The Time Machine was gone!"

edges.label: mistaken for
edges.title: "startling some white animal that, in the dim light, I took for a small deer."

edges.label: surrounded by
edges.title:
"when I woke again it was full day, and a couple of sparrows were hopping round me on the turf
within reach of my arm."

summary: The traveler describes a lush, vibrant world with abundant buildings and life, yet also mysterious wells no water but rhythmic thumping and air currents. Suspecting a subterranean ventilation system unrelated to sanitation, he realizes the less sophisticated lifestyle of the inhabitants differs from expected futures or utopias. Noticing no elderly people and no signs of industry, he contemplates the sustainability of their society. After his Time Machine is taken, he forms a friendly bond with Weena, an Eloi, and learns of their fear of darkness. He discovers Morlocks, a nocturnal underground species, hypothesizing they evolved from humans to operate machinery maintaining the Eloi's lifestyle. The traveler theorizes that class divisions drove humanity into two separate species: the privileged Eloi and laboring Morlocks. He questions the Morlocks' intentions and why the Eloi can't help recover his Machine, while Weena is disturbed by the subject.

nodes.label: Eloi
nodes.title: A race of beautiful, delicate creatures living above ground in a future time

nodes.label: Morlocks
nodes.title: A subterranean species evolved from humans, antagonistic to the Eloi

nodes.label: Weena
nodes.title: A female member of the Eloi who befriends the Time Traveller

nodes.label: Time Traveller
nodes.title: The narrator and central character who explores the future and encounters the Eloi and Morlocks

edges.label: establish friendship
edges.title:
･ The Time Traveller and Weena established a friendship.
･ The Time Traveller appreciated the garland presented by Weena.
･ The Time Traveller experienced distress when leaving Weena exhausted.
･ The Time Traveller found comfort from Weena's devotion.
･ The Time Traveller realized Weena's importance after leaving her.

edges.label: fear
edges.title: Weena feared darkness and black things.

edges.label: observe fear
edges.title: The Time Traveller observed the Eloi's fear of the dark.

summary: The narrator took two days before deciding to investigate the Morlocks, influenced by the Eloi's disgust for them. Disturbed by fear and a sense of duty, he discovered a green structure with an Oriental look but postponed exploring it. The next day, he resolved to descend into the Morlocks' underground domain, despite feeling dread and loneliness. Weena, an Eloi, accompanied him to the well but became distressed when he began his descent. The narrator struggled down the shaft, cramped and at one point nearly falling. Once inside, he rested and encountered three Morlocks who fled from the light of his matches. He observed that Morlocks were carnivorous and lived in a vast cavern with machinery. The narrator used his matches sparingly after realizing he had only a few left. The Morlocks attempted to physically overwhelm him in the dark, but he managed to escape back to the tunnel and eventually the surface after a harrowing climb up the shaft, feeling ill and exhausted. He passed out amidst the comforting presence of Weena and other Eloi.

nodes.label: The Morlocks
nodes.title: A subterranean species perceived as antagonistic, reflecting the Time Traveller's fear and disgust

nodes.label: The Eloi
nodes.title: A surface-dwelling, peaceful species influencing the Time Traveller's emotional state

nodes.label: Weena
nodes.title: A small individual belonging to the Eloi who forms a personal connection with the Time Traveller

nodes.label: The Time Traveller
nodes.title:
The narrator and central character interacting with the Morlocks and the Eloi, experiencing various
challenges

edges.label: felt disgust and feared descending into~
edges.title:
observed, and feared and repulsed, The Time Traveller began to appreciate the Eloi's disgust of the
Morlocks, was hesitant to descend into the well to confront The Morlocks, saw Morlocks retreating
from the light when striking a match, and shouted and scared away The Morlocks when they approached
him.

edges.label: accompanied and reassured
edges.title:
opposed descent, and received affectionately, Weena accompanied The Time Traveller and seemed to
provide reassurance by her presence, showed opposition to The Time Traveller descending into the
well, and kissed The Time Traveller's hands and ears upon his return.

edges.label: approached curiously
edges.title:
attempted stealing, and pursued, The Morlocks approached The Time Traveller in the dark, feeling and
touching, tried to disengage The Time Traveller's matches, and pursued The Time Traveller through
the tunnels.

summary: The Time Traveller feels despair as he contemplates his situation among the Eloi and the Morlocks, realizing the complexity and danger he faces with the latter's antagonistic nature. His hope of escape diminishes with his understanding of the evolved social dynamics between the two species, with the Morlocks preying on the Eloi. Facing these challenges, he resolves to create weapons and find a secure place to sleep. He carries Weena, an Eloi who fears the dark, and they travel toward the Palace of Green Porcelain, which he considers a potential haven. Along the journey, they encounter various obstacles, and the Time Traveller reflects on the fate of humanity, the nature of fear, and the passage of time while seeking solace in the stars. He ponders the Morlocks' food source, realizing the horrific truth, and attempts to rationalize the current state of human devolution. His plan includes creating weapons, finding a means to produce fire, breaking into the Sphinx to retrieve his Time Machine, and possibly bringing Weena back with him.

nodes.label: Time Traveller
nodes.title: The main protagonist who is recounting his experiences with the Eloi and Morlocks in the future

nodes.label: Weena
nodes.title: A member of the Eloi, the future descendants of humanity who forms a bond with the Time Traveller

nodes.label: Morlocks
nodes.title:
A different evolved species from humanity that live underground and have a predatory relationship
with the Eloi

nodes.label: Eloi
nodes.title: The future descendants of humanity that live above ground and are preyed upon by the Morlocks

edges.label: Morlocks
edges.title:
･ Eloi'
･ The Time Traveller carried Weena to protect her from fear and fatigue.

edges.label: disgust
edges.title:
antagonism, study, and fear, The Time Traveller loathed the Morlocks and felt like an enemy would
soon come upon him. The Morlocks studied The Time Traveller and provoked his fear.

edges.label: service and fear
edges.title: The Morlocks made the Eloi's garments and provoked their Fear.

edges.label: fear and dependency
edges.title: The Eloi feared the Morlocks and depended on them for garments.

edges.label: trust and companionship
edges.title:
Weena showed trust in The Time Traveller by sleeping beside him and putting her arms around his neck
for comfort.

sectionName: XI. The Palace of Green Porcelain
summary: The narrator discovers the Palace of Green Porcelain, an ancient museum in a state of decay. Inside, he finds porcelain, inscriptions, fossils, and remnants of various exhibits that hint at past intellectual achievements. He ponders the use and significance of the objects encountered, particularly when finding matches and camphor, which are useful for protection against the Morlocks. Throughout his exploration, he searches for means to protect himself and Weena, considering various tools and weapons he finds among the exhibits, and plans to spend the night near a fire for safety. He maintains hope of regaining his Time Machine despite the advancing night and the threats posed by the Morlocks.

nodes.label: Palace of Green Porcelain
nodes.title: A deserted and falling into ruin palace

nodes.label: Weena
nodes.title: A creature from the future with affectionate behavior

nodes.label: Morlocks
nodes.title: Creatures presumed to be the ones removing cases in the palace

edges.label: does not understand
edges.title:
･ I thought, rather foolishly, that Weena might help me to interpret this, but I only learnt that the
bare idea of writing had never entered her head.
･ Presently came, as I stared about me, and very quietly took my hand and stood beside me.
･ Then Weena’s increasing apprehensions drew my attention.
･ Weena came very close to my side.

edges.label: responsible for
edges.title:
･ And the cases had in some instances been bodily removed—by the Morlocks, as I judged.
･ My sense of the immediate presence of the Morlocks revived at that.
･ And I longed very much to kill a Morlock or so.

edges.label: provided by
edges.title:
I had in my possession a thing that was, perhaps, the best of all defences against the Morlocks—I
had matches!

summary: The narrator traverses a dark forest at night with Weena, gathering wood and fearing attack by Morlocks, an underground species. Weena becomes tired, and when darkness falls, the Morlocks attack. The narrator uses matches for protection but struggles to keep the fire going. Eventually, Weena faints or dies, and the narrator becomes disoriented while fending off the Morlocks. A forest fire starts, confusing and repelling the Morlocks, and in its light, the narrator escapes, leaving behind the Morlocks and Weena. He returns to his Time Machine, feeling alone and overwhelmed by Weena's death, and reflects on his experiences in the future world compared to the familiarity of his own time and home.

nodes.label: Weena
nodes.title: A small, delicate, childlike creature who is part of the Eloi race

nodes.label: Morlocks
nodes.title: A subterranean race of nocturnal creatures who are antagonistic to the Time Traveler and Weena

nodes.label: The Time Traveler
nodes.title: The protagonist and narrator of the story who travels to the future

edges.label: protect
edges.title:
･ The Time Traveler gathered sticks and dried grass for a fire to protect himself and Weena.
･ While loaded with sticks, the Time Traveler's progress was slower, and Weena was tired.
･ Weena would have stopped, fearing the darkness, but The Time Traveler drove onward.
･ The red tongues of fire were a new and strange thing to Weena, and The Time Traveler restrained her
from it.

edges.label: fear
edges.title:
･ The Time Traveler felt fear from the Morlocks, knowing they were approaching in the darkness.
･ The Time Traveler had to struggle and fight against the Morlocks approaching him.

edges.label: attack
edges.title: The Morlocks were closing in upon The Time Traveler, trying to seize him.

edges.label: threaten
edges.title:
While The Time Traveler and Weena hesitated, Morlocks were crouching figures in the darkness,
threatening their safety.

edges.label: fear
edges.title: The Morlocks were driven back by the light and heat of the fire, indicating their fear of it.

sectionName: XIII. The Trap of the White Sphinx
summary: The narrator reflects on the unchanged beauty of the world from his first arrival and the painful memory of Weena. The complacency of the Overworld people is contrasted with the industriousness of the Underworld. Surmising the collapse of the perfect state and the Morlocks' return to old feeding habits, the narrator theorizes on the role of intelligence in survival. After resting by the White Sphinx, he finds the Time Machine unguarded and realizes the Morlocks have tampered with it. Upon entering the machine, he is trapped but eventually escapes, fighting off the Morlocks and engaging the machine to return to his original time.

nodes.label: Weena
nodes.title: A character saved by the narrator from drowning, who is mentioned retrospectively

nodes.label: Morlocks
nodes.title: A subterranean race that the narrator encounters and theorizes about their habits and evolution

nodes.label: Upperworld people
nodes.title:
Inhabitants of the surface world described as beautiful and complacent, lacking the struggles that
breed intelligence

nodes.label: Underworld
nodes.title:
A mechanical and industrious society mentioned as a contrast to the Upperworld, with more initiative
due to their environment

nodes.label: Mother Necessity
nodes.title:
Personification used to describe the fundamental needs and survival instincts that assert themselves
after being staved off, indicative of the return of basic survival challenges

edges.label: examine and clean
edges.title: The Morlocks had partially examined and cleaned the Time Machine

edges.label: cover
edges.title: The beauty of the Overworld people covered the ways to the Underworld

edges.label: come back
edges.title: Mother Necessity came back to the Underworld

summary: The time traveler narrates his disoriented experience with time travel, arriving in the distant future where day and night cycles slow down, and the Earth comes to a standstill with one side facing the sun. The sun appears large and red, life as we know it has vanished, and new monstrous forms of life, resembling large crabs, have emerged. The environment is desolate with red skies, green vegetation in perpetual twilight, and a silent, dead sea. Eventually, the traveler witnesses a significant chill and signs of an advancing ice age, with snow and ice encroaching. During an eclipse, the traveler speculates he might have seen the transit of an inner planet rather than the moon, before an overwhelming darkness and cold prompt him to return to his own time.

nodes.label: Time Traveller
nodes.title: The main character who is travelling through time experiencing strange occurrences

nodes.label: Monstrous Crab-like Creature
nodes.title: A creature encountered by the Time Traveller on the desolate beach

edges.label: encounter
edges.title:
･ "I saw the thing was really a monstrous crab-like creature."
･ "Its vast ungainly claws, smeared with an algal slime, were descending upon me."

edges.label: approach
edges.title:
･ "I saw that, quite near, what I had taken to be a reddish mass of rock was moving slowly towards
me."
･ "Its evil eyes were wriggling on their stalks, its mouth was all alive with appetite."

summary: The Time Traveller returns to his laboratory after a period of insensibility on the machine. He witnesses the reversal of time as he approaches his original time, seeing people and scenery moving backward. He stops the machine feeling shaky and notices the lab looking the same but the machine's displacement reveals the physical journey undertaken. Taking time to recover from his disorientation, he realizes he has returned to the present day when he sees current newspapers and hears familiar voices, leading him to join his companions for dinner and recount his experiences.

nodes.label: Time Traveller
nodes.title: The protagonist who travels through time and experiences changes in the environment and society

nodes.label: Mrs. Watchett
nodes.title:
The housekeeper who crossed the room when the Time Traveller set out and whose motions appeared
reversed when he returned

nodes.label: Hillyer
nodes.title: A character that the Time Traveller seems to see for a fleeting moment upon his return

edges.label: observe
edges.title: The Time Traveller saw Mrs. Watchett walk across the room like a rocket.

edges.label: traverse
edges.title: Mrs. Watchett walked across the laboratory.

edges.label: see
edges.title: The Time Traveller seemed to see Hillyer for a moment.

edges.label: pass by
edges.title: Hillyer passed by The Time Traveller like a flash.

summary: The Time Traveller shares his incredible adventures with a group of disbelieving friends, asking them to accept his story as either truth or fiction. Despite their skepticism, signaled by their various distractions and dismissals, the Traveller maintains that his adventures were real, evidenced by the strange flowers and his own scars. After examining the flowers, the Medical Man expresses doubt, and the Editor suggests the Traveller should be a writer. The Traveller later shows unease about the reality of his experiences and checks his Time Machine to confirm its existence. His abrupt departure and discussions about time travel with the narrator precede another mysterious disappearance, leaving behind a broken skylight and no sign of his return. The narrator reflects on the Traveller's potential whereabouts across various times and ponders the future of mankind, with only withered flowers and memories of the story as comfort. The Time Traveller has been missing for three years, and the narrator is left to wonder if he will ever return.

nodes.label: Time Traveller
nodes.title: The main protagonist who recounts his adventures through time

nodes.label: Medical Man
nodes.title:
A character who is present during the Time Traveller's recounting and is interested in the
scientific aspects of his story

nodes.label: Editor
nodes.title:
A character who expresses skepticism about the Time Traveller's story and wishes the Time Traveller
was a story writer

nodes.label: Journalist
nodes.title:
A character who is also listening to the Time Traveller's account and is concerned with practical
matters, like getting home

nodes.label: Psychologist
nodes.title:
Another member of the audience who exhibits interest in the Time Traveller's story, probably from a
psychological perspective

nodes.label: Weena
nodes.title:
Although not present, she is mentioned by the Time Traveller as the person who gave him flowers; her
role is significant in his personal experiences

nodes.label: Richardson
nodes.title:
A character mentioned at the end implying a planned meeting; his role is minimal in the context of
the story

nodes.label: Man-servant
nodes.title:
The person who appears at the end in the garden, indicating that he was expecting to find the Time
Traveller; has a minor role in the conclusion

edges.label: communicate doubt
edges.title:
･ "I know,” he said, after a pause, “that all this will be absolutely incredible to you. No. I cannot
expect you to believe it."
･ "May I have them?” The Time Traveller hesitated. Then suddenly: “Certainly not.”

edges.label: suggest
edges.title: "What a pity it is you’re not a writer of stories!"

edges.label: express concern
edges.title:
"The Medical Man looked into his face and, with a certain hesitation, told him he was suffering from
overwork."

edges.label: doubt
edges.title: "He thought the tale a “gaudy lie.”"

edges.label: share cab
edges.title: "I shared a cab with the Editor."
